item.title: Bad Bunny Super Bowl Halftime Review: A History Lesson Full of Puerto Rican Pride
item.description: The superstar showcased Puerto Rican pride during a 13-minute set that turned a global opportunity into an intimate, personal performance.
item.dc:creator: Jon Caramanica

item.title: Bad Bunny’s Super Bowl Halftime Show: Best and Worst Moments
item.description: The Puerto Rican superstar’s set included cameos, stunts and powerful statements.
item.dc:creator: Joe Coscarelli, Caryn Ganz, Jacob Gallagher, Jon Pareles, Ben Sisario and Lindsay Zoladz
item.media:description: Bad Bunny led a cast of musicians and dancers for the first Super Bowl halftime set performed nearly entirely in Spanish.

item.title: They Carry a Cake Onstage, and Share Dumplings Off
item.description: Christiani Pitts and Sam Tutty, the stars of the new musical “Two Strangers (Carry a Cake Across New York),” meet for a stroll one blustery afternoon.
item.dc:creator: Douglas Corzine and Marissa Alper
item.category: Two Strangers (Carry a Cake Across New York) (Play)
item.media:credit: Marissa Alper for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tutty said he doesn’t has much time for exploring during the show’s run, but Pitts is still trying to get him off the beaten track.

item.title: A YouTuber’s Film Beat ‘Melania’ at the Box Office. Here’s How.
item.description: “Iron Lung,” a horror movie directed and funded by the video creator known as Markiplier, pulled in $22 million in its first weekend after fans across the country requested screenings.
item.dc:creator: Megan Farokhmanesh
item.media:credit: Natasha Campos/Getty Images For Mark Markiplier
item.media:description: Mark Fischbach, known as Markiplier, directed and funded “Iron Lung” himself.

item.title: Like Fireworks: When Masters of Tap and Kathak Dance Meet
item.description: American tap greats collaborating with kathak dancers discover how to communicate through rhythm.
item.dc:creator: Brian Seibert and Yuvraj Khanna

item.title: Catherine O’Hara Died From Pulmonary Embolism, Death Certificate Says
item.description: A death certificate released on Monday also said rectal cancer was an underlying cause for the comedic actress’s death on Jan. 30 at 71.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor and Matt Stevens
item.media:description: The actress Catherine O’Hara in 2024. She died on Jan. 30 at 71.

item.title: The 2026 Super Bowl Ads, Ranked
item.description: Here is our critic’s survey of this year’s Super Bowl commercials, from best to worst to A.I.
item.dc:creator: Mike Hale
item.media:description: George Clooney pitches Grubhub in one of two Super Bowl ads directed by Yorgos Lanthimos.

item.title: ‘The All-American Halftime’ Featured an Electric Anthem Unlike Hendrix’s
item.description: Turning Point USA’s “All-American” halftime opened with a guitar-solo national anthem. It was a striking contrast to Jimi Hendrix’s rendition at Woodstock.
item.dc:creator: Ben Sisario
item.media:description: Spencer Waasdorp opened Turning Point USA’s “All-American Halftime Show” on Sunday with a take on the national anthem that conveyed a reverent if stubborn form of patriotism.

item.title: Iván Fischer’s Budapest Festival Orchestra Illuminates Mahler’s Third
item.description: Iván Fischer and the Budapest Festival Orchestra led an illuminating journey through one of Mahler’s less heard symphonies at Carnegie Hall.
item.dc:creator: Anastasia Tsioulcas

item.title: Partying With Charli XCX at Sundance After Premiere of ‘The Moment’
item.description: The “Brat” pop star isn’t afraid to lean into her party-girl persona. But moving into film with “The Moment” has given her brand-new perspective.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan and Sinna Nasseri
item.media:description: For most of her career, Charli saw herself as “famous but not quite.”

item.title: DGA Winners 2026: Paul Thomas Anderson’s Oscar Momentum Builds
item.description: The filmmaker beat out Ryan Coogler, Guillermo del Toro, Josh Safdie and Chloé Zhao. The prize is a strong predictor of the Oscars.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan
item.media:description: Paul Thomas Anderson at the Directors Guild Awards on Saturday night.

item.title: Bad Bunny Delivers Joyful Super Bowl Halftime Show
item.description: Lady Gaga and Ricky Martin joined the Puerto Rican musician in a show that celebrated Latino heritage and was performed mostly in Spanish. His appearance had become a political flashpoint amid his criticism of ICE.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Loren Elliott for The New York Times

item.title: The Child in Bad Bunny’s Halftime Show Was an Actor
item.description: There was much speculation about the boy’s identity. The young actor posted on social media about his experience as part of Bad Bunny’s performance.
item.dc:creator: Emmanuel Morgan

item.title: ‘Send Help’ and Other Great Movies About Castaways
item.description: “Send Help” is just the latest take on a survivalist premise that dates to the 1719 novel “Robinson Crusoe.” These six movies offer fascinating twists.
item.dc:creator: Rumsey Taylor
item.category: Portrait of a Lady on Fire (Movie)

item.title: Jon Stewart Defends Bad Bunny’s Super Bowl Halftime Show
item.description: “The Daily Show” host said it shouldn’t be a performer’s job to unify the country: “Isn’t there another person whose job description is much more along those lines?”
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: The Daily Show with Jon Stewart (TV Program)
Have I Got News for You (TV Program)

item.title: ‘Love Story,’ Plus 6 Things to Watch on TV This Week
item.description: The Ryan Murphy series about John F. Kennedy Jr. and Carolyn Bessette premieres, and a new A24 non-scripted series airs.
item.dc:creator: Shivani Gonzalez
item.media:description: Sarah Pidgeon and Paul Kelly in “Love Story.”

item.title: Bad Bunny’s Super Bowl Halftime Show: Takeaways and Best Moments
item.description: Popcast’s immediate thoughts after Bad Bunny took the stage for a tribute to his native Puerto Rico.
item.dc:creator: Jon Caramanica, Joe Coscarelli, Sophie Erickson, Kate LoPresti, Andrew Smith, Chris Moore, Pat Gunther and Nick Pitman
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by The New York Times; Photo: Loren Elliott for The New York Times

item.title: Bad Bunny Delivers a Love Letter to Puerto Rico at Super Bowl Halftime
item.description: His performance featured a sugar cane field, a wedding seemingly officiated onstage and a New York-style street scene, along with appearances by Lady Gaga and Ricky Martin.
item.dc:creator: Jon Pareles, Ben Sisario and Lindsay Zoladz
item.media:credit: Loren Elliott for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bad Bunny’s halftime set featured a replica of a sugar-cane field and scores of backup dancers.

item.title: Turning Point USA’s Halftime Show Pays Tribute to Charlie Kirk
item.description: Kid Rock was the headliner at the streamed concert pitched as a conservative alternative to Bad Bunny’s main event at the Super Bowl on Sunday night.
item.dc:creator: Marc Tracy
item.media:description: Kid Rock at the Republican National Convention in 2024. He performed Sunday night in an alternative halftime show for Turning Point USA.

item.title: Green Day Condemns ICE as Part of Super Bowl Festivities
item.description: The band’s frontman, Billie Joe Armstrong, urged Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents to quit their jobs, warning that the Trump administration would inevitably abandon them.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: Billie Joe Armstrong of Green Day performing before the kickoff of the Super Bowl on Sunday.

item.title: Bad Bunny’s Sign Language Interpreter Will Make Super Bowl History, Too
item.description: Puerto Rican Sign Language is not the same as American Sign Language. Celimar Rivera Cosme will uniquely capture the rapper’s slang for the game’s deaf viewers.
item.dc:creator: Emmanuel Morgan
item.media:description: Celimar Rivera Cosme interpreted for Bad Bunny during his world tour in 2022 and his 31-show residency in San Juan last year. The Super Bowl will be by far her biggest stage.

item.title: Key Moments on Bad Bunny’s Path to the Super Bowl Halftime Show
item.description: He’s had big hits, won awards, co-starred with Adam Sandler and even came out on top at WrestleMania. Here’s how the 31-year-old star got to music’s biggest stage.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Abrams
item.media:description: Well over 100 million people are expected to watch Bad Bunny perform at the Super Bowl.

item.title: Haruki Murakami Isn’t Afraid of the Dark
item.description: The author, who brought Japanese literature into the global mainstream, grapples with aging and his place in the world of letters.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Alter
item.media:credit: Dana Scruggs for The New York Times

item.title: Brad Arnold, Rocker Who Fronted 3 Doors Down, Dies at 47
item.description: He wrote the band’s breakout hit, “Kryptonite,” in a high school math class, and would go on to be nominated for three Grammy Awards.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: Brad Arnold, center, performing with 3 Doors Down at the Lincoln Memorial in Washington in 2017, in honor of Donald J. Trump’s first inauguration.

item.title: Suzannah Lessard Dies at 81; Stanford White Descendant Who Wrote a Haunting Family Memoir
item.description: Growing up in a family of secrets, on a compound designed by her great-grandfather, made her a writer who investigated the built world with a wary eye.
item.dc:creator: Penelope Green
item.media:credit: Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Suzannah Lessard in 1996, on the balcony of the Players club in Manhattan, designed by her great-grandfather Stanford White.

item.title: Ejae, Sombr: 9 Songs We’re Talking About This Week
item.description: Ejae and Sombr chased the Grammys with new releases, and Peter Gabriel began unfurling his next album.
item.dc:creator: Jon Pareles
item.media:credit: Emma McIntyre/Getty Images for the Recording Academy
item.media:description: Ejae, who sings lead on the “KPop Demon Hunters” smash “Golden,” released a solo single.

item.title: 5 Super Bowl Halftime Shows That Sparked Controversies
item.description: America’s largest stage has become the locus of a few heated conversations about politics, culture or propriety.
item.dc:creator: Marc Hogan
item.media:description: The term “wardrobe malfunction” entered the public lexicon after the 2004 halftime show.

item.title: This ‘Summer House’ Star Loves to Eat Like a Child
item.description: “Technically, I’m a toddler,” said Ciara Miller, who is back for the 10th season of the Bravo reality show. “Or I have the diet of one.”
item.dc:creator: Shivani Gonzalez

item.title: Super Bowl Halftime Is the World’s Biggest Stage. He Designs It.
item.description: From Prince’s giant symbol to Kendrick Lamar’s streetlamps, the set production designer Bruce Rodgers “makes the impossible possible.”
item.dc:creator: Emmanuel Morgan
item.media:description: “People are hungry for spectacle and excitement and things they can talk about the next day,” said Bruce Rodgers, who works with the N.F.L. and artists to design the halftime shows.

item.title: ‘Melania’ and the Real Housewives of Washington
item.description: The documentary highlights a few notable predecessors in the role, burnishing Mrs. Trump’s image by extension. But one apt comparison is pointedly left out.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson

item.title: Body of Nathan Smith, Lil Jon’s Son, Found in Georgia Pond, Police Say
item.description: Nathan Smith, whose stage name is DJ Young Slade, was reported missing on Tuesday after running out of his home in a community north of Atlanta.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Ziegler
item.media:credit: Kevin Mazur/Getty Images for Pencils of Promise
item.media:description: The rapper Lil Jon, left, with his son, Nathan Smith, in 2018. The police said the body of Mr. Smith was recovered from a pond in Georgia on Friday.

item.title: White House Suggests Smithsonian Add a Trump Display
item.description: Administration officials met with staff at the Smithsonian’s National Portrait Gallery and discussed putting multiple artworks of the president in a section of the museum.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Small and Robin Pogrebin
item.media:description: The Smithsonian changed President Trump’s portrait in the National Gallery last month to an image by the photographer Daniel Torok.

item.title: These ceremonies have a tough act to follow: Italy’s last Olympics spectacle.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:description: At the opening ceremony of Winter Games in Turin, Italy, in 2006, an athlete struck an anvil with a hammer, each blow setting off pyrotechnics.

item.title: Review: Alexei Ratmansky, Ballet’s King of Comedy, Fights Back
item.description: At New York City Ballet, Alexei Ratmansky exposes the current moment with a political satire based on “The Emperor’s New Clothes.”
item.dc:creator: Gia Kourlas

item.title: Timothy Busfield Is Indicted on Charges of Child Sexual Abuse
item.description: A grand jury in New Mexico heard allegations that Mr. Busfield, the actor and director, had sexual contact with a child actor. He has denied the charges.
item.dc:creator: Julia Jacobs
item.media:description: Prosecutors filed a criminal complaint against Timothy Busfield last month accusing him of sexual contact with a child. He has denied the charges.

item.title: ‘A Knight of the Seven Kingdoms’ Season 1, Episode 4 Recap: Is There No True Knight?
item.description: Ser Duncan faces a bigger test of his mettle than even he bargained for after assaulting a prince — about six extra knights’ worth.
item.dc:creator: Sean T. Collins
item.category: A Knight of the Seven Kingdoms (TV Program)
item.media:description: Ser Duncan (Peter Claffey), still gazing heavenward.

item.title: Five International Movies to Stream Now
item.description: This month’s picks include a Korean political satire, an Indian thriller set in the world of dog-breeding, a biopic of a Czech athlete-turned-porn star and more.
item.dc:creator: Devika Girish

item.title: 9 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
item.description: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: 5 Children’s Movies to Stream Now
item.description: This month’s picks include the newest installment in a sci-fi saga for teenagers and a feature version of a beloved TV show for tots.
item.dc:creator: Dina Gachman

item.title: Bad Bunny’s All-American, All-Spanish, All-Eyes-on-Him Super Bowl Halftime Show
item.description: Amid harsh rhetoric from the White House, the Puerto Rican superstar will take the stage on Sunday promising a message of unity: “The world will dance.”
item.dc:creator: Ben Sisario
item.media:credit: Amy Lombard for The New York Times; Erika Santelices/Reuters; Emily Kask for The New York Times;

item.title: ‘High Spirits’ Review: A Ghostly Delight From Encores!
item.description: A revival of a 1964 musical, which puts a supernatural spin on a Noël Coward play, features a starry cast: Andrea Martin, Phillipa Soo, Steven Pasquale and Katrina Lenk.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli
item.category: Encores! Great American Musicals in Concert (Series)

item.title: Farewell, Pocket Books
item.description: Our books reporter Elizabeth A. Harris explores the disappearance of mass market paperbacks — and talks with Stephen King about what paperbacks have meant to him.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth A. Harris, Léo Hamelin and Laura Salaberry

item.title: ‘Queen of Chess’ Review: The Surprising Story of a Grandmaster
item.description: Framed as a sports tale, “Queen of Chess,” directed by Rory Kennedy, recounts the life of Judit Polgar, who battled sexism as much as rival players.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson

item.title: 7 Brothers, a Rom-com and a Dream
item.description: These siblings (and an in-law) turned their childhood love of Hollywood into a family enterprise that has resulted in “Solo Mio,” starring Kevin James.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr
item.media:credit: George Etheredge for The New York Times
item.media:description: The brothers have been making movies together since childhood. From left: Wil, Jeff Azize (actually a brother-in-law), Pete, Dan, Brendan, Chuck, Pat and John.

item.title: Saying Goodbye to the Mass Market Paperback
item.description: The mass market paperback, light in the hand and on the wallet, once filled airport bookstores and supermarket media aisles. You may never buy a new one again.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth A. Harris

item.title: The Fight Between a Watch Heiress and an Art Museum on the French Riviera
item.description: An eccentric watch heiress wants to revoke her grandfather’s donation of Jean Cocteau artworks after the museum built to display them was overwhelmed by a freakish storm.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Small and Théo Giacometti

item.title: Late Night Finds Trump Out of Place at Prayer Breakfast
item.description: The annual National Prayer Breakfast “is supposed to be a normal, nonpartisan event,” Seth Meyers said, “but, of course, Donald Trump is incapable of being normal.”
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)

item.title: ‘The Pitt’ Season 2, Episode 5 Recap: Reunited
item.description: Robby and Langdon finally collide, and the vibe is predictably tense. That sabbatical can’t some soon enough.
item.dc:creator: Sean T. Collins
item.media:description: Dr. Robby and Dr. Langdon (Noah Wyle, left, and Patrick Ball) were thrown back together by a very scary case. Prognosis: touch-and-go.

item.title: Smithsonian Folklife Festival Gives Way to Trump’s Patriotic Fair
item.description: The summer festival, held annually since 1967, will not take place as usual on the National Mall, which will instead host the president’s Great American State Fair.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Schuessler
item.media:description: A traditional Inuit blanket toss at the Smithsonian Folklife Festival in 1974.

item.title: ‘The Strangers: Chapter 3’ Review: Devils in Disguise
item.description: The final installment in the trilogy reboot of “The Strangers,” a genuinely terrifying 2008 home invasion film, brings the masked nonsense to a close.
item.dc:creator: Erik Piepenburg

item.title: ‘Moulin Rouge!’ Musical Will End Its Broadway Run This Summer
item.description: The final New York performance will be July 26, seven years after it opened; international and touring productions continue.
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson
item.media:description: The show, which opened in 2019, won the Tony Award for best musical at a pandemic-delayed ceremony held in 2021.

item.title: Savannah Guthrie’s Video Shows a Rare and Anguished Reality
item.description: Morning show hosts have shown a vulnerable, candid side to their audiences before, but not like this.
item.dc:creator: James Poniewozik

item.title: Art Gallery Shows to See in February
item.description: This week in Newly Reviewed, Andrew Russeth covers Keith Haring’s rollicking murals, John Duff’s gritty inventiveness and a group show focused on the human body.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Russeth

item.title: The Philadelphia Museum of Art Restores Its Old Name
item.description: After an unpopular name change, and its firing of the director responsible for it, the museum is working to rehabilitate its image.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Small
item.media:credit: Hannah Yoon for The New York Times
item.media:description: A rebrand last year had changed the name of the Philadelphia Museum of Art to the Philadelphia Art Museum.

item.title: Ted Berger, Indefatigable Patron of Artists and Schools, Dies at 85
item.description: As head of the New York Foundation for the Arts, he oversaw almost $23 million in grants and helped bring arts education to struggling schools.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.category: New York Foundation for the Arts
item.media:description: Ted Berger in 2006. “We, the artists, are the facade of what Ted has built here in New York,” the composer Meredith Monk said. “And Ted is our foundation.”

item.title: Toni Morrison’s Best Books: A Guide
item.description: Her novels reveal a deeply American desire for freedom and adventure, and one of her work’s great joys lies in always finding something new to discover. Here’s where to start.
item.dc:creator: Veronica Chambers

item.title: ‘Sirat’ Review: A Shocker in the Desert
item.description: The Galician director Oliver Laxe delivers a mesmerizing thriller about a man’s search for his lost daughter, set amid raves in the punishing Sahara.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis

item.title: Tom Stoppard Is Gone. In ‘Arcadia,’ His Wit Still Sparkles.
item.description: A new London production of the playwright’s masterpiece has extra poignancy just months after his death.
item.dc:creator: Houman Barekat

item.title: Carnegie Hall’s 2026-27 Season: What We Want to Hear
item.description: Highlights include the hall’s first “Ring,” cycles of sonatas by Beethoven and Mozart and a birthday celebration for Steve Reich.
item.media:credit: Byron Smith for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Berlin Philharmonic, which will open Carnegie Hall’s season in October, playing there in 2016.

item.title: Jimmy Kimmel Hints ‘Melania’ Box Office Was a ‘Rigged Outcome’
item.description: Late night hosts were skeptical of a $7 million opening weekend for the new Amazon film about the first lady.
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)

item.title: Outside the Art World’s Echo Chamber, at Art Basel Qatar
item.description: More than half the exhibited artists were from the Middle East, North Africa or South Asia, giving visitors an opportunity to discover fresh voices.
item.dc:creator: Scott Reyburn
item.category: Sheikha Al Mayassa bint Hamad bin Khalifa Al Thani
item.media:credit: Adriane de Souza for The New York Times
item.media:description: A work by El Anatsui at the October Gallery booth at Art Basel in Doha, Qatar.

item.title: One Episode of ‘Wonder Man’ Points a Way Forward for the Marvel Universe
item.description: Marvel’s character-driven show on Disney+ provides an intriguing alternative to the company’s big-screen spectacles.
item.dc:creator: Maya Phillips
